intro: Quercus tinctoria var. californica, commonly known as the California tan oak, is a deciduous tree native to coastal and inland regions of California. It is characterized by its deep green, lobed leaves that turn bronze in the fall. The tree produces small, red acorns that are encased in a cupule, providing food for wildlife. It typically grows to a height of 20–40 feet with a broad, rounded crown. This species is adapted to a variety of soil types but thrives in well-drained, rocky soils.
